questions.question_text: Which six-byte field in a basic Ethernet frame must be an individual address?

DRAG DROP -
Drag each category on the left to its corresponding router output line on the right. Each router output line is in the result of a show ip interface command. Not all categories are used.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content: The correct order is not: 1. port operational; 2. Layer 2 problem; 3. Layer 1 problem; 4. port disabled ? I know from my experience if interface is up, line protocol is down, it's a Layer 2 problem. Please correct me.
geogvn1994 is in the correct way... the correct order is: 1 port operational; 2 Layer 1 problem; 3 Layer 2 problem; 4 port disabled
i'm with geogvn on this one

choices.D: The R3 router ID is configured on R6. D
choices.A: There is an area ID mismatch.
choices.B: There is a PPP authentication issue; the username is not configured on R3 and R6.
choices.C: There is an OSPF hello and dead interval mismatch.

questions.answer_description:
Here are the relevant parts of the router configs:


We are not sure about the configuration of ppp authentication in this case. Some reports said that only one router has the "ppp authentication chap" command but it is just a trick and is not the problem here. The real problem here is R6 uses the same router-id of R3 (192.168.3.3) so OSPF neighborship cannot be established. In real life, such configuration error will be shown in the command line interface (CLI). So please check carefully for this question.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
the Router ID is same on R3 and R6 , thats why the ospf neighbours are not establishing between r3 and r6
the Router ID is same on R3 and R6 , thats why the ospf neighbours are not establishing between r3 and r6
the Router ID is same on R3 and R6 , thats why the ospf neighbours are not establishing between r3 and r6
show the console screens or remove this question. This question is not helpful.

questions.question_text: What are two requirements for an HSRP group? (Choose two)

discussion.content:
It hink "A" and "C" are corretcs!

It's all about concept. In HSRP only one active router and one standby router can assume these roles within a group, it is not possible that 2 or more routers assume the standby role or appears on the output of the "show standby" command. The third , fourth, and son on, routers, are considered backup routers and they only assume the standby role if the active or standby router in operation goes down.

By concept "One or more backup virtual routers" are required for an HSRP group.

choices.C: one or more backup virtual routers

questions.question_text: If primary and secondary root switches with priority 16384 both experience catastrophic losses, which tertiary switch can take over?

discussion.content: this is a trap question... A is correct because if the tertiary switch have 4096 priority, it should be the root. In this case the root and secondary are greater than 16000 so if they go down, the tertiary switch with the lowest priority is 20480
